cloud_connector.page.title: Cloud Connector
cloud_connector.page.description: Redirect traffic from your website or application to a defined storage bucket on Cloudflare R2 or supported third parties like AWS, Google Cloud, and Azure.

cloud_connector.landing.onboard.modal.st: Easily connect to your cloud storage buckets
cloud_connector.landing.onboard.modal.bo: Make Cloudflare the control center for your web traffic by enabling connections between your website or application, and cloud storage.
Set custom rules for your web traffic
Select your bucket location and customize when your web traffic is redirected to that bucket.
cloud_connector.landing.onboarding.modal: How to build a Cloud Connector
cloud_connector.landing.onboard.modal.bo: Choose from Cloudflare R2 or popular 3rd party providers like Google Cloud and Amazon S3.
Choose your R2 bucket or enter the details for your 3rd party bucket to send traffic directly to that location.
Like the other Rules features, you can set up filter settings to customize what traffic is redirected.

HTTP response headers
managed_header_modifications.group.add_b: Adds HTTP request headers with bot-related values: bot score, verified bot, threat score, JA3 and JA4 fingerprints.
managed_header_modifications.group.add_c: Adds HTTP request headers with <0>Mutual TLS (mTLS) client authentication values</0>.
managed_header_modifications.group.add_v: Adds HTTP request headers with location information for the visitor's IP address, including city, country, continent, longitude, and latitude.
managed_header_modifications.group.add_m: Adds a header 'Malicious-Uploads-Detection' to requests that provides the result from scanning uploaded content for malicious signatures. Learn more about <0>Malicious Uploads Detection.</0>
managed_header_modifications.group.remov: Removes HTTP request headers that may contain the visitor's IP address. Unavailable when "Add True-Client-IP header" is enabled.
managed_header_modifications.group.add_x: Adds several security-related HTTP response headers providing cross-site scripting (XSS) protection and defining a Content Security Policy (CSP).
managed_header_modifications.group.remov: Removes the "X-Powered-By" HTTP response header that provides information about the application at the origin server that handled the request.
managed_header_modifications.group.add_s: Adds several security-related HTTP response headers providing cross-site scripting (XSS) protection.
managed_header_modifications.group.add_t: Adds a "True-Client-IP" request header with the visitor's IP address. Unavailable when "Remove visitor IP headers" is enabled.
managed_header_modifications.group.add_w: Adds a header 'Exposed-Credential-Check' that provides values on fields which have been found to be leaked. <0>Learn more about Leaked Credential Checks</0>.

page-rules.additional-page-rules.title: Additional Page Rules
page-rules.description: Page Rules let you control which Cloudflare settings trigger on a given URL. Only one Page Rule will trigger per URL, so it is helpful if you sort Page Rules in priority order, and make your URL patterns as specific as possible.
page-rules.error.always_use_https.must_c: The URL must begin with "http://" for Always Use HTTPS to work.
page-rules.help:
### What are Page Rules?

Page Rules give you granular, URL-based control of Cloudflare's settings. The most important thing to know about Page Rules is that only one Page Rule will trigger on a URL, so it's important to sort your Page Rules in priority order, and keep your most specific Page Rules at the top.

#### What patterns are allowed in Page Rules?

 If you are using a Forwarding Page Rule, then you can map those wildcards to variables. In the forwarding URL, you can specify $1, $2 and so on that match the wildcards in the original URL, in order from left to right.

 For example, you could forward `http://*.example.com/*` to `http://$2.example.com/$1.jpg`. This rule would match `http://cloud.example.com/flare`, which would end up being forwarded to `http://flare.example.com/cloud.jpg`.

#### Some helpful tips:

1. If you want to match both http and https, it is enough to write example.com. You don't need to do *example.com.
2. If you want to match every page on a domain, you need to write example.com/*. It is not enough to write example.com.
3. Refer to [Page Rules](https://developers.cloudflare.com/rules/page-rules/) for more details on Page Rule patterns.

#### What does Cache Everything do?

 In Page Rules, you can select an additional Caching Level that is only available in Page Rules: Cache Everything.  Cache Everything caches all content including html and dynamic/personalized content. That said, use with caution. It caches HTTP codes `200`, `301`, `302`, `303`, `403` and `404`. (Other HTTP response codes can be cached by specifying the URL and setting the Edge Cache TTL to "respect existing headers", assuming the origin allows caching.)

#### How do you specify cookie names for Bypass Cache Cookie or Cache on Cookie?

 *Note that Bypass Cache on Cookie is available only on Business and Enterprise plans & Cache on Cookie is Enterprise only.*
You can specify multiple cookie names by using the OR "|" operator. For example, to match `cookie1`, `cookie2`, or `cookie3`, you would write: `cookie1|cookie2|cookie3`. You can also use the wildcard ".*" operator, i.e. `cookie1.*`.

#### Bypass Cache on Cookie (Business & Enterprise) Tutorials: 

* [Caching Static HTML with WordPress/WooCommerce](https://support.cloudflare.com/hc/articles/236166048)
* [Caching Static HTML with Magento (version 1 & 2)](https://support.cloudflare.com/hc/articles/236168808)
* [Caching HTML with Drupal](https://support.cloudflare.com/hc/articles/115002911927)
* [How do I cache static HTML?](https://developers.cloudflare.com/cache/concepts/customize-cache/) 

#### What do Resolve Override and Host Header Override do (Enterprise only)?

 Resolve Override changes the origin address that a request to a URL will be sent to. Host Override changes the Host Header on requests to that URL. More information is available on our knowledge base about [Resolve Override](https://support.cloudflare.com/hc/articles/206190798) and [Host Header Override](https://support.cloudflare.com/hc/articles/206652947).

 By using the asterisk (*) character, you can create dynamic patterns that can match many URLs, rather than just one. All URLs are case insensitive.
 [Learn more about Page Rules](https://developers.cloudflare.com/rules/page-rules/).

transform-rules.page.description: Adjust the URI path, query string, and HTTP headers of requests and responses at the edge. Transformed traffic is then used as input for other Cloudflare products.

transform-rules.tab.rewrite-url.descript: Return the content of a rewritten URL from the origin server. The visitor's browser will still display the original URL.
transform-rules.description: Use Transform Rules to transform your traffic. This includes URL Normalization, URL Rewrites, and Header Modifications. Transformed traffic is then used as input for other Cloudflare products.

transform-headers.response_header.modify: You can modify up to %{count} response headers
transform-headers.request_header.form.to:
**Set header**
u2022 Replaces all existing header fields of a request with the entered value.
u2022 Adds the entered value to requests without any headers.
u2022 Where possible, we will keep the header in the same position.

**Remove header**
Removes all headers with this header name. If a header with this name does not exist, no action is taken.
transform-headers.response_header.form.t:
**Add header**
Adds a new response header with the entered value, keeping any existing headers with the same name.

**Set header**
u2022 Replaces all existing header fields of a response with the entered value.
u2022 Adds the entered value to responses without any headers.
u2022 Where possible, we will keep the header in the same position.

**Remove header**
Removes all headers with this header name. If a header with this name does not exist, no action is taken.
transform.configuration.normalization_ty: RFC-3986: Adhere strictly to RFC-3986 and normalize the URI Path based upon the standards outlined within.
Cloudflare: Apply additional normalization techniques; normalize back slashes into forward slashes and merge successive forward slashes.
Further information on these options can be found within the <0>documentation.</0>
transform.configuration.normalize_incomi: Normalize incoming URL-encoded URLs as they reach Cloudflareu2019s edge. Cloudflare then uses the normalized URLs for products with URL input, including Page Rules, WAF custom rules, Workers, and Access.
transform.configuration.normalize_origin: In addition to URL normalization at Cloudflareu2019s edge, normalize URLs for traffic to the origin.
snippets.promo.title: Unlock custom logic at the edge
snippets.promo.description: Take control of your edge configuration with <0>Cloudflare Snippets</0> u2014 short, powerful pieces of JavaScript that dynamically tailor your website or application. Available at no extra cost on Pro, Business, and Enterprise plans.
snippets.promo.benefit.1:
**Advanced customisation made simple**
Modify headers, validate JWTs, perform complex rewrites and redirects, retry to different origins, and more.
snippets.promo.benefit.2:
**Precision through code and rules**
Seamlessly combine JavaScript with rules to target specific requests. Execute multiple Snippets sequentially, with each building on the modifications of the last.
snippets.promo.benefit.3:
**Included with paid plans**
Snippets are available at no extra cost on Pro, Business, and Enterprise plans.
snippets.promo.footer: Explore Snippets in action with real-world examples in the <0>Snippets documentation.</0>
snippets.page.title: Snippets
snippets.page.description: Cloudflare Snippets are short pieces of JavaScript code that can be used to customize the behavior of your applications running on the Cloudflare platform. They can be used for a variety of tasks, such as customizing HTTP response headers, Implementing JWT validation and complex redirect functionality. Snippets provide a flexible and powerful way to customize the behavior of your website or application.
snippets.onboarding.title: Welcome to Snippets!
snippets.onboarding.description: Snippets provide a flexible and powerful way to customize the behavior of your website or application using short pieces of JavaScript code. Create snippets to customize HTTP response headers, implement JWT validation, define complex redirect functionality, and more.

rules.overview.description: Modify HTTP requests and responses, perform URL redirects, configure Cloudflare settings and trigger actions for matching requests. Rules are evaluated and executed in order, from first to last. If multiple rules make the same modification, the last executed rule wins.
rules.overview.page.title: Overview
rules.overview.configuration_rules.confi: The setting is |||| The settings are
rules.overview.sidepanel.traffic_sequenc: Modify Cloudflare configurations, caching, or compression
rules.overview.templates.starter.title: Rule templates
rules.overview.toolbar.active_tooltip: You have used %{used} out of %{max} active %{product}
rules.settings.bulk_redirects.title: Bulk Redirect Lists
rules.settings.bulk_redirects.descriptio: You have used %{countLists} of %{maxLists} redirect lists and %{countRules} of %{maxRules} items. These lists are shared between all domains in your account.
rules.settings.url_normalization.descrip: Normalize incoming URLs before any rules are evaluated.
rules.settings.custom_error_assets.title: Custom Error Assets
rules.settings.custom_error_assets.descr: Store assets that can be used to display error pages based on <0>custom error rules.</0>
rules.settings.custom_error_assets.table: A custom error asset is stored at the time it is saved and needs to be fetched again if it is modified on the origin.
You don't have custom error assets
Create your first custom error asset
Create a custom error rule for this asset
Are you sure you want to delete this asset?
You cannot delete an asset that is being used by rules
Please confirm that you want to delete %{assetName}.
Store assets to display as error pages for custom error rules
The asset will be fetched and stored upon save. You can manually trigger another fetch to get the latest version if it has been modified on your origin.
